overview: India is utilizing Contracts for Difference (CfD) to secure green finance for its renewable energy goals, aiming to achieve 500 GW of renewable energy capacity by 2030 and its broader climate targets.
key_points: India is using Contracts for Difference (CfD) to attract USD 1 trillion in green finance.
CfDs stabilize revenue for renewable energy producers by offsetting market price fluctuations.
India needs substantial green finance (USD 2.5 trillion by 2030, USD 10 trillion by 2070) to meet its climate goals, including its net-zero target.
Green finance is essential for India's sustainable development and achieving its commitments under the Paris Agreement.

important_terms.definition: A financial agreement that stabilizes revenues for renewable energy producers; the government pays the difference if market prices fall below an agreed price, and the producer returns the surplus if prices rise above it.
Financial products and services designed to promote environmental sustainability.
The agreed-upon price in a CfD; used to calculate payments between the government and the producer.

processes_or_flows.title: CfD Mechanism
steps: Renewable energy producer and government agree on a strike price.
If market price < strike price: Government pays producer the difference.
If market price > strike price: Producer pays government the difference.

examples: National Clean Energy and Environment Fund (NCEEF) funded by coal cess.
Indian Renewable Energy Development Agency (IREDA) concessional loans.
Priority Sector Lending (PSL) mandated by the Reserve Bank of India.
